Award.AwardTitle: Solving the Type Ia Supernova Progenitor Puzzle
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund a combined theoretical and observational study to address the origins of Type Ia supernovae. Dr. Di Stefano and her collaborators will create extensive population synthesis simulations that employ observations to compute the appearance of supernovae at two stages of evolution: during an epoch when a white dwarf gains mass and during a possible second epoch, when the white dwarf may need to spin down before it can explode. This group will compute the expected signatures in, and mine existing large data sets for, supernova progenitors in recent large surveys to identify the locations some of the thousands of progenitors that inhabit the Milky Way and Magellanic Clouds.

In recent years, astronomers have proposed that these stellar explosions may have come from a variety of situations involving compact stellar remnants such as white dwarfs. Understanding the origins of supernovae is viewed as a key issue in improving studies of the history of the expansion of the universe. Dr. Di Stefano will also continue her efforts in public education and outreach, and will include students at many different levels (high school through graduate school) in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most stars travel through the Galaxy with a stellar companion.  In many stellar binaries the stars exchange mass, and each influences the future of the other. Binaries also alter their environments. Binarity is, for example, responsible for the bright explosions, Type Ia supernovae, that astronomers have used to discover that the expansion of the Universe is accelerating. Our project was designed to discover important clues to help solve the "Type Ia progenitor puzzle". The missing piece of the puzzle is the still-mysterious nature or natures of the binaries which become Type Ia supernovae.

The most massive star (the "primary") in a Type Ia supernova progenitor binary evolves to become a white dwarf which, either through gradual mass gain or merger, eventually becomes massive enough to explode. The first element of our work was therefore to learn about the initial states of those binaries with primary stars in the right mass range (generally above five solar masses). We wanted to know: how massive is the companion star? how large is its orbit? is the orbit circular or eccentric? We need to know the binary's initial state in order to track its  evolution and determine if it will ever go supernova. Oddly enough, this important study had not been tackled, largely because a good deal was known about less massive binaries, and it was thought that the same principles would apply. Our work demonstrated, however, that the world of massive binaries is more complicated. The new features we discovered significantly influence the evolutionary paths followed by binaries that have massive white dwarfs. A legacy of this NSF program will be that reliable calculations of the frequency of a wide range of binary phenomena, from variable binaries to novae and Type Ia supernovae, will now start with a firm foundation.

To establish our results we studied eclipsing binaries identified in a unique set of data collected by the OGLE team, which conducts a wide-field survey. Wide-field surveys are becoming more important in astronomy. A frontline NSF-supported survey, the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), will begin observations within the next 6-8 years. The methods we developed can be used to analize many of the eclipsing binaries LSST will discover.

Our research also led to an unexpected discovery: young binaries (called by the press ``mismatched twins in a stellar nursery'') in which one star was already on the main sequence, and the other was still bloated. This is, in stellar terms, a very short-lived state which provides clues to stellar and binary formation.

We also considered a new effect that received some pubic attention: the influence of impacts by planets and asteroids. We made a definite prediction of bright events which can be observed even in other galaxies when a planetoid collides with a white dwarf. The possible role of such collisions in facilitating supernovae, either through enrichment of the white dwarf or other effects, is not certain, but is a topic for future research by the community.

We incorporate our work on young binaries into calculations of the evolution of a set of binaries that almost certainly play a role in some Type Ia supernovae.  Specifically, we are focusing on symbiotic binaries, which contain a white dwarf and a giant star in a wide orbit. Finally, we also conducted a study directed toward understanding what the progenitors of Type Ia supernovae look like: can we recognize them when we see them in external galaxies?
